duraludon: Its metal body is durable but prone to retaining heat. It vents this heat from the slits in its tail.
dreepy: It has a habit of biting at Clauncher even though it doesn't feed on them. This is said to be vestigial behavior from when Dreepy was alive.
drakloak: This Pokémon stores up energy in its lungs, then shoots it out. It takes care of Dreepy and battles alongside them until they're all grown up.
dragapult: The fastest Dragapult of the group is always surrounded by Dreepy that want to fly at sonic speed.
kleavor: This Pokémon is a rough, crude, and violent sort. It swings around its large, heavy stone axes to finish off its prey.
ursaluna-1: This special Ursaluna can see in the dark with its left eye and protects itself with mud that is as hard as iron.
basculegion: It can jump with incredible power. Parts of its body are tinged red by the rage of its fallen friends.
basculegion-1: It can afflict a target with terrifying illusions that are under its control. The deeper the sadness in its friends' souls, the paler Basculegion becomes.
overqwil: It's ferocious and has a short temper. The ends of its spikes are barbed, and they can't be easily removed once they've punctured something.
sprigatito: The sweet scent its body gives off mesmerizes those around it. The scent grows stronger when this Pokémon is in the sun.
floragato: The hardness of Floragato's fur depends on the Pokémon's mood. When Floragato is prepared to battle, its fur becomes pointed and needle sharp.
meowscarada: With skillful misdirection, it rigs foes with pollen- packed flower bombs. Meowscarada sets off the bombs before its foes realize what's going on.
fuecoco: Its flame sac is small, so energy is always leaking out. This energy is released from the dent atop Fuecoco's head and flickers to and fro.
crocalor: The valve in Crocalor's flame sac is closely connected to its vocal cords. This Pokémon utters a guttural cry as it spews flames every which way.
skeledirge: Skeledirge's gentle singing soothes the souls of all that hear it. It burns its enemies to a crisp with flames of over 5,400 degrees Fahrenheit.
quaxly: Its strong legs let it easily swim around in even fast-flowing rivers. It likes to keep things tidy and is prone to overthinking things.
quaxwell: The hardworking Quaxwell observes people and Pokémon from various regions and incorporates their movements into its own dance routines.
quaquaval: Dancing in ways that evoke far-away places, this Pokémon mesmerizes all that see it. Flourishes of its decorative water feathers slice into its foes.
lechonk: This Pokémon spurns all but the finest of foods. Its body gives off an herblike scent that bug Pokémon detest.
oinkologne: It entrances female Pokémon with the sweet, alluring scent that wafts from all over its body.
oinkologne-1: This is a meticulous Pokémon that likes to keep things tidy. It shrouds itself in a floral aroma that soothes the Pokémon around it.
tarountula: The thread it secretes from its rear is as strong as wire. The secret behind the thread's strength is the topic of ongoing research.
spidops: Spidops covers its territory in tough, sticky threads to set up traps for intruders.
nymble: It's highly skilled at a fighting style in which it uses its jumping capabilities to dodge incoming attacks while also dealing damage to opponents.
lokix: It uses its normally folded third set of legs when in Showdown Mode. This places a huge burden on its body, so it can't stay in this mode for long.
pawmi: The pads of its paws are electricity-discharging organs. Pawmi fires electricity from its forepaws while standing unsteadily on its hind legs.
pawmo: Pawmo uses a unique fighting technique in which it uses its forepaws to strike foes and zap them with electricity from its paw pads simultaneously.
pawmot: Pawmot's fluffy fur acts as a battery. It can store the same amount of electricity as an electric car.
tandemaus: The pair sticks together no matter what. They split any food they find exactly in half and then eat it together.
maushold: The little one just appeared one day. They all live together like a family, but the relationship between the three is still unclear.
maushold-1: The larger pair protects the little ones during battles. When facing strong opponents, the whole group will join the fight.
fidough: The yeast in Fidough's breath is useful for cooking, so this Pokémon has been protected by people since long ago.
dachsbun: The surface of this Pokémon's skin hardens when exposed to intense heat, and its body has an appetizing aroma.
smoliv: This Pokémon converts nutrients into oil, which it stores in the fruit on its head. It can easily go a whole week without eating or drinking.
dolliv: It basks in the sun to its heart's content until the fruits on its head ripen. After that, Dolliv departs from human settlements and goes on a journey.
arboliva: This Pokémon drives back enemies by launching its rich, aromatic oil at them with enough force to smash a boulder.
squawkabilly: Green-feathered flocks hold the most sway. When they're out searching for food in the mornings and evenings, it gets very noisy.
squawkabilly-1: Blue-feathered Squawkabilly view their green- feathered counterparts as rivals, since the latter make up the largest, most powerful groups.
squawkabilly-2: The yellow Squawkabilly are especially fierce. They've even been known to drive other bird Pokémon out of town.
squawkabilly-3: Though these Squawkabilly are the fewest in number, they have no trouble living in towns since they blend in with the white buildings.
nacli: The ground scrapes its body as it travels, causing it to leave salt behind. Salt is constantly being created and replenished inside Nacli's body.
naclstack: It compresses rock salt inside its body and shoots out hardened salt pellets with enough force to perforate an iron sheet.
garganacl: Many Pokémon gather around Garganacl, hoping to lick at its mineral-rich salt.
charcadet: Its firepower increases when it fights, reaching over 1,800 degrees Fahrenheit. It likes berries that are rich in fat.
armarouge: This Pokémon clads itself in armor that has been fortified by psychic and fire energy, and it shoots blazing fireballs.
ceruledge: An old set of armor steeped in grudges caused this Pokémon's evolution. Ceruledge cuts its enemies to pieces without mercy.
tadbulb: It floats using the electricity stored in its body. When thunderclouds are around, Tadbulb will float higher off the ground.
bellibolt: What appear to be eyeballs are actually organs for discharging the electricity generated by Bellibolt's belly-button dynamo.
wattrel: These Pokémon make their nests on coastal cliffs. The nests have a strange, crackling texture, and they're a popular delicacy.
kilowattrel: It uses its throat sac to store electricity generated by its wings. There's hardly any oil in its feathers, so it is a poor swimmer.
maschiff: Its well-developed jaw and fangs are strong enough to crunch through boulders, and its thick fat makes for an excellent defense.
mabosstiff: Mabosstiff loves playing with children. Though usually gentle, it takes on an intimidating look when protecting its family.
shroodle: To keep enemies away from its territory, it paints markings around its nest using a poisonous liquid that has an acrid odor.
grafaiai: Each Grafaiai paints its own individual pattern, and it will paint that same pattern over and over again throughout its life.
bramblin: Not even Bramblin knows where it is headed as it tumbles across the wilderness, blown by the wind. It loathes getting wet.
brambleghast: Brambleghast wanders around arid regions. On rare occasions, mass outbreaks of these Pokémon will bury an entire town.
toedscool: Though it looks like Tentacool, Toedscool is a completely different species. Its legs may be thin, but it can run at a speed of 30 mph.
toedscruel: It coils its 10 tentacles around prey and sucks out their nutrients, causing the prey pain. The folds along the rim of its head are a popular delicacy.
klawf: This Pokémon lives on sheer cliffs. It sidesteps opponents' attacks, then lunges for their weak spots with its claws.
capsakid: Traditional Paldean dishes can be extremely spicy because they include the shed front teeth of Capsakid among their ingredients.
scovillain: The green head has turned vicious due to the spicy chemicals stimulating its brain. Once it goes on a rampage, there is no stopping it.
rellor: It rolls its mud ball around while the energy it needs for evolution matures. Eventually the time comes for it to evolve.
rabsca: An infant sleeps inside the ball. Rabsca rolls the ball soothingly with its legs to ensure the infant sleeps comfortably.
flittle: It spends its time running around wastelands. If anyone steals its beloved berries, it will chase them down and exact its revenge.
espathra: It emits psychic power from the gaps between its multicolored frills and sprints at speeds greater than 120 mph.
tinkatink: This Pokémon pounds iron scraps together to make a hammer. It will remake the hammer again and again until it's satisfied with the result.
tinkatuff: These Pokémon make their homes in piles of scrap metal. They test the strength of each other's hammers by smashing them together.
tinkaton: The hammer tops 220 pounds, yet it gets swung around easily by Tinkaton as it steals whatever it pleases and carries its plunder back home.
wiglett: Though it looks like Diglett, Wiglett is an entirely different species. The resemblance seems to be a coincidental result of environmental adaptation.
wugtrio: A variety of fish Pokémon, Wugtrio was once considered to be a regional form of Dugtrio.
bombirdier: Bombirdier uses the apron on its chest to bundle up food, which it carries back to its nest. It enjoys dropping things that make loud noises.
finizen: Its water ring is made from seawater mixed with a sticky fluid that Finizen secretes from its blowhole.
palafin: Its physical capabilities are no different than a Finizen's, but when its allies are in danger, it transforms and powers itself up.
palafin-1: This hero of the ocean swims at a speed of 50 knots and saves drowning people and Pokémon.
varoom: The steel section is Varoom's actual body. This Pokémon clings to rocks and converts the minerals within into energy to fuel its activities.
revavroom: Revavroom viciously threatens others with the sound of its exhaust. It sticks its tongue out from its cylindrical mouth and sprays toxic fluids.
cyclizar: It can sprint at over 70 mph while carrying a human. The rider's body heat warms Cyclizar's back and lifts the Pokémon's spirit.
orthworm: This Pokémon lives in arid deserts. It maintains its metal body by consuming iron from the soil.
glimmet: Glimmet's toxic mineral crystals look just like flower petals. This Pokémon scatters poisonous powder like pollen to protect itself.
glimmora: Glimmora's petals are made of crystallized poison energy. It has recently become evident that these petals resemble Tera Jewels.
greavard: This friendly Pokémon doesn't like being alone. Pay it even the slightest bit of attention, and it will follow you forever.
houndstone: A lovingly mourned Pokémon was reborn as Houndstone. It doesn't like anyone touching the protuberance atop its head.
flamigo: Thanks to a behavior of theirs known as “synchronizing,” an entire flock of these Pokémon can attack simultaneously in perfect harmony.
cetoddle: It lives in frigid regions in pods of five or so individuals. It loves the minerals found in snow and ice.
cetitan: Ice energy builds up in the horn on its upper jaw, causing the horn to reach cryogenic temperatures that freeze its surroundings.
veluza: Veluza has excellent regenerative capabilities. It sheds spare flesh from its body to boost its agility, then charges at its prey.
dondozo: It treats Tatsugiri like its boss and follows it loyally. Though powerful, Dondozo is apparently not very smart.
tatsugiri: Tatsugiri is an extremely cunning Pokémon. It feigns weakness to lure in prey, then orders its partner to attack.
tatsugiri-1: This Pokémon tricks its opponents by playing dead. It is small and weak, but it uses its smarts to survive.
tatsugiri-2: It's one of the most intelligent dragon Pokémon. It camouflages itself by inflating its throat sac.
annihilape: It imbues its fists with the power of the rage that it kept hidden in its heart. Opponents struck by these imbued fists will be shattered to their core.
clodsire: It lives at the bottom of ponds and swamps. It will carry Wooper on its back and ferry them across water from one shore to the other.
farigiraf: The hardened head from the tail protects the head of the main body as Farigiraf whips its long neck around to headbutt enemies.
dudunsparce: It drives enemies out of its nest by sucking in enough air to fill its long, narrow lungs, then releasing the air in an intense blast.
dudunsparce-1: A recent study uncovered that the number of segments a Dudunsparce's body has is determined by the Pokémon's genes.
kingambit: Though it commands a massive army in battle, it's not skilled at devising complex strategies. It just uses brute strength to keep pushing.
greattusk: This creature resembles a mysterious Pokémon that, according to a paranormal magazine, has lived since ancient times.
screamtail: It resembles a mysterious Pokémon described in a paranormal magazine as a Jigglypuff from one billion years ago.
brutebonnet: It bears a slight resemblance to a Pokémon described in a dubious magazine as a cross between a dinosaur and a mushroom.
fluttermane: It has similar features to a ghostly pterosaur that was covered in a paranormal magazine, but the two have little else in common.
slitherwing: This Pokémon somewhat resembles an ancient form of Volcarona that was introduced in a dubious magazine.
sandyshocks: It slightly resembles a Magneton that lived for 10,000 years and was featured in an article in a paranormal magazine.
irontreads: Sightings of this Pokémon have occurred in recent years. It resembles a mysterious object described in an old expedition journal.
ironbundle: It resembles a mysterious object mentioned in an old book. There are only two reported sightings of this Pokémon.
ironhands: This Pokémon shares many similarities with Iron Hands, an object mentioned in a certain expedition journal.
ironjugulis: It's possible that Iron Jugulis, an object described in an old book, may actually be this Pokémon.
ironmoth: No records exist of this species being caught. Data is lacking, but the Pokémon's traits match up with an object described in an old book.
ironthorns: Some of its notable features match those of an object named within a certain expedition journal as Iron Thorns.
frigibax: This Pokémon lives in forests and craggy areas. Using the power of its dorsal fin, it cools the inside of its nest like a refrigerator.
arctibax: It attacks with the blade of its frozen dorsal fin by doing a front flip in the air. Arctibax's strong back and legs allow it to pull off this technique.
baxcalibur: It launches itself into battle by flipping upside down and spewing frigid air from its mouth. It finishes opponents off with its dorsal blade.
gimmighoul: It lives inside an old treasure chest. Sometimes it gets left in shop corners since no one realizes it's actually a Pokémon.
gimmighoul-1: It wanders around, carrying an old coin on its back. It survives by draining the life-force from humans who try to pick up its coin.
gholdengo: It has a sturdy body made up of stacked coins. Gholdengo overwhelms its enemies by firing coin after coin at them in quick succession.
wochien: It drains the life-force from vegetation, causing nearby forests to instantly wither and fields to turn barren.
chienpao: The hatred of those who perished by the sword long ago has clad itself in snow and become a Pokémon.
tinglu: It slowly brings its exceedingly heavy head down upon the ground, splitting the earth open with huge fissures that run over 160 feet deep.
chiyu: The envy accumulated within curved beads that sparked multiple conflicts has clad itself in fire and become a Pokémon.
roaringmoon: According to an article in a dubious magazine, this Pokémon has some connection to a phenomenon that occurs in a certain region.
ironvaliant: It's possible that this is the object listed as Iron Valiant in a certain expedition journal.
koraidon: This Pokémon resembles Cyclizar, but it is far burlier and more ferocious. Nothing is known about its ecology or other features.
koraidon-1: It has similar characteristics to a creature described in an old book as the Winged King.
miraidon: This seems to be the Iron Serpent mentioned in an old book. The Iron Serpent is said to have turned the land to ash with its lightning.
miraidon-1: It was given the name Miraidon by the professor who discovered it. Its ecology and other details are unknown.
walking wake: It resembles an illustration published in a paranormal magazine, said to be a depiction of a super-ancient Suicune.
ironleaves: According to the few eyewitness accounts that exist, it used its shining blades to julienne large trees and boulders.
dipplin: The head sticking out belongs to the fore-wyrm, while the tail belongs to the core-wyrm. The two share one apple and help each other out.
poltchageist: Poltchageist looks like a regional form of Sinistea, but it was recently discovered that the two Pokémon are entirely unrelated.
poltchageist-1: It has taken up residence in a very expensive tea caddy. It takes an expert to distinguish the expensive tea caddies from the cheap ones.
sinistcha: It prefers cool, dark places, such as the back of a shelf or the space beneath a home's floorboards. It wanders in search of prey after sunset.
sinistcha-1: The more stirring it does with the tea whisk on its head, the more energy it builds up. It does this to prepare for battle.
okidogi: Okidogi is a ruffian with a short temper. It can pulverize anything by swinging around the chain on its neck.
munkidori: Munkidori keeps itself somewhere safe while it toys with its foes, using psychokinesis to induce intense dizziness.
fezandipiti: Fezandipiti beats its glossy wings to scatter pheromones that captivate people and Pokémon.
ogerpon: This mischief-loving Pokémon is full of curiosity. It battles by drawing out the type-based energy contained within its masks.
ogerpon-1: In this form, it draws on the power of water. It attacks unrelentingly with kicks and ivy strikes.
ogerpon-2: In this form, it draws on the power of fire. It spears its enemies with thorn-covered ivy.
ogerpon-3: In this form, it draws on the power of stone. Its body is rock-solid, protecting it from all manner of attacks.
archaludon: It digs holes on mountains, searching for food. It's so durable that being caught in a cave-in won't faze it.
hydrapple: These capricious syrpents have banded together. On the rare occasion that their moods align, their true power is unleashed.
gougingfire: It resembles an eerie Pokémon once shown in a paranormal magazine. That Pokémon was said to be an Entei regenerated from a fossil.
ragingbolt: It bears resemblance to a Pokémon that became a hot topic for a short while after a paranormal magazine touted it as Raikou's ancestor.
ironboulder: It was named after a mysterious object recorded in an old book. Its body seems to be metallic.
ironcrown: There was supposedly an incident in which it launched shining blades to cut everything around it to pieces. Little else is known about it.
terapagos: It's thought that this Pokémon lived in ancient Paldea until it got caught in seismic shifts and went extinct.
terapagos-1: The shell is made of crystallized Terastal energy. When struck by a move, this shell absorbs the move's energy and transfers it to Terapagos.
terapagos-2: An old expedition journal describes the sight of this Pokémon buried in the depths of the earth as resembling a planet floating in space.
pecharunt: Its peach-shaped shell serves as storage for a potent poison. It makes poisonous mochi and serves them to people and Pokémon.
